body:
> at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

At first, "everyone" was Adam and Eve and their family. Humanity hasn't been anywhere near as corrupt as before the flood ever since then, aside from a few specific instances. When's the last time a civilization was destroyed for that?

> Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again

Again, because "everyone" here is Noah and his family.

> there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

I don't see how it's gotten worse. Outside of a few third-world countries, when is the last time people were burned alive on the streets and thrown in arenas to be ripped to shreds by wild animals, enjoyed by a sadistic audience of everyday people? Do people still have slaves that they rape and kill regularly (and even women and children)? This is how the most "civilized" people used to act, not just a few antifa looters here and there. Times are certainly not perfect now, but I don't know how you could think that they were better before.

> to include greece, rome, and now the US, among others.

Greece and Rome were strongest when they deluded themselves and had no morals. When Christianity spread in Rome, morality increased and prevented them from doing many of the immoral things necessary to maintain such an empire. In fact, aside from having to be brutal, such faith in the "greatness" of their empires is pride and idolatry. Don't look back at Rome and Greece and think they had some kind of great morality, that's just nostalgia.

Please bear in mind, tradition ≠ morality.

> but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked? Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

Yes, people don't keep slaves and kids that they make do all their work and assault them for pleasure, people don't get turned into candles or ripped apart by wild animals for not worshipping the emperor, most people are actually willing to do *some* negotiating and have a better idea of justice than "You did something bad to me so I'm killing your whole family slowly and painfully and burning your house down and looting all you have and raping and assaulting you and chopping your body parts off one by one until you die!". Today, we have that kind of thing in, say, North Korea. That used to be almost everything. People are still like their ancestors at heart but they are at least willing to keep some control over it now. And about parents not feeling comfortable letting their kids outside anymore, media. Nowadays we hear about every story all over the news, and on top of that our recent culture has been *way* too nanny-like, worrying about every tiny thing that could possibly happen and thinking we have to do everything we can to make sure everything is perfect and nothing ever happens. It's not because the world is actually so dangerous now, and if it were it's because there's a lot more people in it, not because they're worse in general.

> As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.

*All* people are like this, which is why I don't trust people in general. Changing which demographics can vote isn't going to solve this problem, it just silences them. That's worse, because even people with good intentions cannot understand the lives of people besides themselves, and don't always make the right judgements. "Some/average people are too foolish" is the same argument used by monarchs to justify their "divine right" to rule over people. They're 100% correct about people being foolish, but miss that they themselves are usually even worse. It's hypocritical, and it's why I agree with Thomas Hobbes's premise but have no idea how that led him to his conclusion. People are evil, so how can you trust them to control things?
body_html:
at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

At first, "everyone" was Adam and Eve and their family. Humanity hasn't been anywhere near as corrupt as before the flood ever since then, aside from a few specific instances. When's the last time a civilization was destroyed for that?

Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again

Again, because "everyone" here is Noah and his family.

there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

I don't see how it's gotten worse. Outside of a few third-world countries, when is the last time people were burned alive on the streets and thrown in arenas to be ripped to shreds by wild animals, enjoyed by a sadistic audience of everyday people? Do people still have slaves that they rape and kill regularly (and even women and children)? This is how the most "civilized" people used to act, not just a few antifa looters here and there. Times are certainly not perfect now, but I don't know how you could think that they were better before.

to include greece, rome, and now the US, among others.

Greece and Rome were strongest when they deluded themselves and had no morals. When Christianity spread in Rome, morality increased and prevented them from doing many of the immoral things necessary to maintain such an empire. In fact, aside from having to be brutal, such faith in the "greatness" of their empires is pride and idolatry. Don't look back at Rome and Greece and think they had some kind of great morality, that's just nostalgia.

Please bear in mind, tradition ≠ morality.

but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked? Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

Yes, people don't keep slaves and kids that they make do all their work and assault them for pleasure, people don't get turned into candles or ripped apart by wild animals for not worshipping the emperor, most people are actually willing to do some negotiating and have a better idea of justice than "You did something bad to me so I'm killing your whole family slowly and painfully and burning your house down and looting all you have and raping and assaulting you and chopping your body parts off one by one until you die!". Today, we have that kind of thing in, say, North Korea. That used to be almost everything. People are still like their ancestors at heart but they are at least willing to keep some control over it now. And about parents not feeling comfortable letting their kids outside anymore, media. Nowadays we hear about every story all over the news, and on top of that our recent culture has been way too nanny-like, worrying about every tiny thing that could possibly happen and thinking we have to do everything we can to make sure everything is perfect and nothing ever happens. It's not because the world is actually so dangerous now, and if it were it's because there's a lot more people in it, not because they're worse in general.

As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.

All people are like this, which is why I don't trust people in general. Changing which demographics can vote isn't going to solve this problem, it just silences them. That's worse, because even people with good intentions cannot understand the lives of people besides themselves, and don't always make the right judgements. "Some/average people are too foolish" is the same argument used by monarchs to justify their "divine right" to rule over people. They're 100% correct about people being foolish, but miss that they themselves are usually even worse. It's hypocritical, and it's why I agree with Thomas Hobbes's premise but have no idea how that led him to his conclusion. People are evil, so how can you trust them to control things?

parent.body:
The world collectively has always been bad, yes; but as time goes on it takes stronger root.  Consider for example the period of time between creation and the flood: at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again, until Jesus came and shined his light upon the world, and things got a little better, there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

That's looking at the world collectively; then if you look at individual nations, you can discern a moral decay leading to the fall of many great nations, to include greece, rome, and now the US, among others. 

Whether this country itself was ever ordained of God can be debated, i don't necessarily think it was, but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked?  Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.
parent.body_html:
The world collectively has always been bad, yes; but as time goes on it takes stronger root. Consider for example the period of time between creation and the flood: at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again, until Jesus came and shined his light upon the world, and things got a little better, there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

That's looking at the world collectively; then if you look at individual nations, you can discern a moral decay leading to the fall of many great nations, to include greece, rome, and now the US, among others.

Whether this country itself was ever ordained of God can be debated, i don't necessarily think it was, but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked? Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.

parent.body:
Excellent, polytheist, now go to verse 9:

"Love must be sincere. Hate what is evil; cling to what is good"

And the letter is adressing the community in Rome. The early "Christian" communities didn't intermingle with the general population, nor did they practise Roman patriotism (quite the opposite). 

Paul also said that the citizenship of the elect (not Christians) was not in the world, but in heaven. And Jesus himself said his followers (not Christians) were not of the world, and 1 John 5 says the world is in the hand of the evil one.

So much for your devout faith, huh? 

And btw, what was the name of the hospital and surgeon where you saw a magical tumour (that didn't at all behave like any tumour) miracoulusly removed?

body: Yes, and I can see where you're going with the "increase in wickedness" part. But that's referring to the *very* end, when the great persecutions occur again (but even worse) and the antichrist arrives. That hasn't happened just yet, and for now we're living in a period of relative peace compared to most of history. Even just a few centuries ago, you'd be facing the threat of torture and execution if you dared proclaim the truth. Now all you need to worry about is some strangers making rude remarks (unless you try to talk at an Antifa rally or something, but that's the exception, not the institutionalized norm).
body_html: Yes, and I can see where you're going with the "increase in wickedness" part. But that's referring to the very end, when the great persecutions occur again (but even worse) and the antichrist arrives. That hasn't happened just yet, and for now we're living in a period of relative peace compared to most of history. Even just a few centuries ago, you'd be facing the threat of torture and execution if you dared proclaim the truth. Now all you need to worry about is some strangers making rude remarks (unless you try to talk at an Antifa rally or something, but that's the exception, not the institutionalized norm).

parent.body:
That's not an unpopular opinion here, but sure, I'll take it on.

You don't think Palestinians and by extension, Muslims, have any cause to dislike Jews?

When people say things that are antisemitic, they're not talking about Neil who works at the bakery or something like that. They're talking about the general attitudes of Orthodox Jews who believe everyone else is cattle, as well as the control the Jewish community has over our politicians and the narratives that people believe in this country.

Look up Lakewood, New Jersey and see what happened there. The town was taken over by Orthodox Jews. They would (and still) use aggressive and illegal tactics to try and get people to sell their houses, which would then be bought by other Orthodox Jews. Their educational budget has been completely destroyed, since money has gone to Yeshivas as well as to transport to and from those Yeshivas. Since the Jews became populous enough to control local politics, these things have gotten much worse there. It's not all that much different from what they do when they create their settlements in Palestine.

What about Jews punching way above their weight in our media and entertainment industries? This matters, because these industries largely control what people believe. Or in politics - why does the fate, security, and finances of Israel have to take precedence over so many other important issues?

How about the "great for thee, not for me" mentality regarding refugees? Jews tend to push multiculturalism in every other country but wouldn't even discuss such a thing happening in Israel. Can you imagine any other religion or culture demanding, and getting their own highly militarized ethnostate with no question? 

Also the shifting identity that many of them choose to do doesn't warm any hearts, claiming they're White when criticizing Whites, but claiming they're not White, but Jewish, when being held accountable for something White people supposedly did.

As far as meeting a few goes, it doesn't mean anything with that small sample size and that small amount of time you spent with them. I've met a few felons and they were pretty good people for the most part, so what? My own experiences with more casual Jews have been fine. But the effect of that culture on the West has been extremely negative.

That's not an unpopular opinion here, but sure, I'll take it on.

You don't think Palestinians and by extension, Muslims, have any cause to dislike Jews?

When people say things that are antisemitic, they're not talking about Neil who works at the bakery or something like that. They're talking about the general attitudes of Orthodox Jews who believe everyone else is cattle, as well as the control the Jewish community has over our politicians and the narratives that people believe in this country.

Look up Lakewood, New Jersey and see what happened there. The town was taken over by Orthodox Jews. They would (and still) use aggressive and illegal tactics to try and get people to sell their houses, which would then be bought by other Orthodox Jews. Their educational budget has been completely destroyed, since money has gone to Yeshivas as well as to transport to and from those Yeshivas. Since the Jews became populous enough to control local politics, these things have gotten much worse there. It's not all that much different from what they do when they create their settlements in Palestine.

What about Jews punching way above their weight in our media and entertainment industries? This matters, because these industries largely control what people believe. Or in politics - why does the fate, security, and finances of Israel have to take precedence over so many other important issues?

How about the "great for thee, not for me" mentality regarding refugees? Jews tend to push multiculturalism in every other country but wouldn't even discuss such a thing happening in Israel. Can you imagine any other religion or culture demanding, and getting their own highly militarized ethnostate with no question?

Also the shifting identity that many of them choose to do doesn't warm any hearts, claiming they're White when criticizing Whites, but claiming they're not White, but Jewish, when being held accountable for something White people supposedly did.

As far as meeting a few goes, it doesn't mean anything with that small sample size and that small amount of time you spent with them. I've met a few felons and they were pretty good people for the most part, so what? My own experiences with more casual Jews have been fine. But the effect of that culture on the West has been extremely negative.

post.body:
i don't know how to defend my point this time tbh, it just baffles me. i haven't met a lot of jews in my life, and probably neither have you, but when i did, there was nothing outstanding about them. i bet you don't even know if a person is a jew or not, until they tell you or you hear their name or something.

it reminds me of a conversation i had with an indian friend of mine, where he showed me a few screenshots of his conversation with an anonymous partner on omegle. everything went well for them until their partner asked where they were from, he replied "india" and then their partner started spouting racist nonsense. i mean what the fuck man, you wouldn't have even known where they were from if they themselves didn't tell you, why the hatred?

author.bio:

body: This is one of the rare moments in history when being thrown into the dens of carnivores has not been the norm. I'm not denying that it could start back up in the very near future, things can change surprisingly fast. But I wouldn't say people are worse right *now*, you just tend to feel like that when it's the time you're living in, as everyone does. Please note that I'm not saying people are getting *better* over time either, just because I don't think that they're worse than ever now. Indeed they will get much worse again at some point.

I'm not denying that it could start back up in the very near future, things can change surprisingly fast. But I wouldn't say people are worse right now, you just tend to feel like that when it's the time you're living in, as everyone does. Please note that I'm not saying people are getting better over time either, just because I don't think that they're worse than ever now. Indeed they will get much worse again at some point.

guild.description_html: Got a burning unpopular opinion you want to share? Spark some discussions!

parent.body:
It goes through cycles, or waves if you will, does it not?  We may be living in a time or relative peace, and yet be facing a time of extreme persecution.  I would say the true body of Christ is facing pretty severe persecution, but we don't see it because its not given the same sort of attention as Trump having the flu.  Whether it is done openly would have a difference on your perception, would it not?  And worldly history books are curated by Satan, no? Much of what has happened in the way of persecution is hidden in mainstream history, im not sure how much youve studied it (i dont claim to be an expert) but the picture i builds suggests a sort of cyclical but still ever increasing persecution.

You can choose to interpret Matthew 24, but there are other references to wicked increasing over time in the scripture, to include what we can only assume happened between the time of creation and the flood.

I agree that there have been times of severe barbarism to include what you talked about in Rome with galdiator fights and what not, but if i understand correctly that was toward the point of fullness of wickedness, or at least thats my understanding of it. In other words, you may be able to watch the same thing on TV in 10 years from now.  Consider the progression from boxing to ufc for example, and people's demands and cries for blood are ever increasing.  The murder mystery section of libraries has no shortage of choices. Pedophilia and incest is being openly advocated for and the boundries are being pushed further and further every year.
parent.body_html:
It goes through cycles, or waves if you will, does it not? We may be living in a time or relative peace, and yet be facing a time of extreme persecution. I would say the true body of Christ is facing pretty severe persecution, but we don't see it because its not given the same sort of attention as Trump having the flu. Whether it is done openly would have a difference on your perception, would it not? And worldly history books are curated by Satan, no? Much of what has happened in the way of persecution is hidden in mainstream history, im not sure how much youve studied it (i dont claim to be an expert) but the picture i builds suggests a sort of cyclical but still ever increasing persecution.

You can choose to interpret Matthew 24, but there are other references to wicked increasing over time in the scripture, to include what we can only assume happened between the time of creation and the flood.

I agree that there have been times of severe barbarism to include what you talked about in Rome with galdiator fights and what not, but if i understand correctly that was toward the point of fullness of wickedness, or at least thats my understanding of it. In other words, you may be able to watch the same thing on TV in 10 years from now. Consider the progression from boxing to ufc for example, and people's demands and cries for blood are ever increasing. The murder mystery section of libraries has no shortage of choices. Pedophilia and incest is being openly advocated for and the boundries are being pushed further and further every year.

body:
Yes, but that's the whole point. Peoples' nature has always been just as bad at heart, it's just like you said a matter of how much they try to hide it. And they hide it more now than they have in most periods of history. People being evil is nothing new, though some seem to think it is.

There are plenty of third world countries where similar barbarism happens today, but keep in mind that this was characteristic of the *most civilized* nations back in the day; the others were even *worse*. It's easy to get nostalgic and romanticize those time periods, but in reality they weren't so great.
body_html:
Yes, but that's the whole point. Peoples' nature has always been just as bad at heart, it's just like you said a matter of how much they try to hide it. And they hide it more now than they have in most periods of history. People being evil is nothing new, though some seem to think it is.

There are plenty of third world countries where similar barbarism happens today, but keep in mind that this was characteristic of the most civilized nations back in the day; the others were even worse. It's easy to get nostalgic and romanticize those time periods, but in reality they weren't so great.

Just because we're not being thrown into lions dens doesn't mean that people's thirst to see blood and death is not the same, rather just that its not done openly.

The measure of suffering that occurs, in my opinion, is likely still greater now than it was then, although we do agree that at this moment in time, and at this geographical location, things aren't too bad.  South Africa on the other hand, things are pretty bad there, not sure if you've heard what's happening/what has been happening there for the past decade or maybe more.

post.title: Giving women the right to vote was a mistake

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
On its own, the updates are very good. But they're focusing on all the wrong things. Minecraft used to be about building a bunch of stuff, optionally with a few monsters to make it harder, and that's how it was played. Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. And yes it does take away from what it is, many of the new updates change the whole core mechanics that had been so iconic and in place for years. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

I think it initially started with Beta 1.7/1.8 when Jeb took over, but back then at least it was just some controversial decisions and not completely ridding the original genre. But the updates since 1.9 have upped this to the tenth power. After the Adventure update (Beta 1.8) many people didn't like how things had changed directions, but looking back Infdev-b1.7.3 vs b1.8-1.7.10 actually have a lot more more in common with each other than they do with current Minecraft! They even felt the need to change all the textures and models because it's just not the same game anymore.

On a brighter note, the cave update is the first in forever that looks like it might actually bring something to the building and mining part, so that's good. But it doesn't matter to me, since I've never adapted to 1.9+.
body_html:
On its own, the updates are very good. But they're focusing on all the wrong things. Minecraft used to be about building a bunch of stuff, optionally with a few monsters to make it harder, and that's how it was played. Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. And yes it does take away from what it is, many of the new updates change the whole core mechanics that had been so iconic and in place for years. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

I think it initially started with Beta 1.7/1.8 when Jeb took over, but back then at least it was just some controversial decisions and not completely ridding the original genre. But the updates since 1.9 have upped this to the tenth power. After the Adventure update (Beta 1.8) many people didn't like how things had changed directions, but looking back Infdev-b1.7.3 vs b1.8-1.7.10 actually have a lot more more in common with each other than they do with current Minecraft! They even felt the need to change all the textures and models because it's just not the same game anymore.

On a brighter note, the cave update is the first in forever that looks like it might actually bring something to the building and mining part, so that's good. But it doesn't matter to me, since I've never adapted to 1.9+.

parent.body: What do you miss being able to do that you can't now? 1.7 beta is about where I got into it, so maybe some nostalgia for older versions is lost on me, but what I loved about having a little world where I build my things and explore is still there, except with more materials to choose from, more places to explore and different mobs to make it interesting. I agree that not all updates were good or focused on the right thing - I didn't like the direction the texture pack took either, the underground is in a sorry state and even terrain generation could really have been made more interesting by now, but generally I found it pretty easy to just not bother with the things I don't care about. I get that a lot specifics on how things are done changed, but you can still play it as a game where you build stuff + monsters.
parent.body_html: What do you miss being able to do that you can't now? 1.7 beta is about where I got into it, so maybe some nostalgia for older versions is lost on me, but what I loved about having a little world where I build my things and explore is still there, except with more materials to choose from, more places to explore and different mobs to make it interesting. I agree that not all updates were good or focused on the right thing - I didn't like the direction the texture pack took either, the underground is in a sorry state and even terrain generation could really have been made more interesting by now, but generally I found it pretty easy to just not bother with the things I don't care about. I get that a lot specifics on how things are done changed, but you can still play it as a game where you build stuff + monsters.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body: Based on your what you've said, it sounds like you're assuming we're the last generation in existence and that the final 7 years is just around the corner. While I cannot confirm or deny that, every generation in history has thought the same thing and I try to be more careful about jumping to those kinds of conclusions. Everything always looks worse from your own perspective, so it's easy to look at all the awful things in life today and think "it couldn't be worse!". We've been seeing small signs but that's been happening the whole time, I don't see anything special about now so far. I do agree that this is the general end times, as has been the case for ~2000 years, but I don't think we're at the *very* end currently.
body_html: Based on your what you've said, it sounds like you're assuming we're the last generation in existence and that the final 7 years is just around the corner. While I cannot confirm or deny that, every generation in history has thought the same thing and I try to be more careful about jumping to those kinds of conclusions. Everything always looks worse from your own perspective, so it's easy to look at all the awful things in life today and think "it couldn't be worse!". We've been seeing small signs but that's been happening the whole time, I don't see anything special about now so far. I do agree that this is the general end times, as has been the case for ~2000 years, but I don't think we're at the very end currently.

parent.body:
2 Timothy 3:13, and also the four beasts in daniel, with the fourth being exeedingly dreadful and diverse from those before it.

I would agree that superficially the world appears less wicked, but i none the less believe that the world, *collectively*, has never been more wicked.
